Dacia was a region inhabited by the Dacians in the north of the Danube (modern Romania and Moldova, as well as parts of Ukraine, Eastern Serbia, Northern Bulgaria, Slovakia, Hungary and Southern Poland). The Dacians were a Thracian people and were considered by the Romans and Greeks as the relatives of the Getae, who had a different dialect than Dacian.

The Dacians had a centralized kingdom in the 1st century BCE under King Burebista, who led successful military campaigns and created a powerful state. The kingdom reached its peak under King Decebalus (87-106 CE), when its territory stretched from the Black Sea to the Tisza River and from the Balkan Mountains to the Carpathian Mountains.

The Dacians engaged in several wars with the Roman Empire, especially under Emperor Trajan. Following the Dacian Wars (101-102 CE and 105-106 CE), Dacia was conquered and transformed into a Roman province. The Dacians were known for their military prowess, craftsmanship in gold and silver, and distinctive religious practices centered around their chief deity, Zalmoxis.
